OK Foods, Inc.

Muldrow, Oklahoma



Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary       



1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES.



OK Foods, we utilize anhydrous ammonia in a closed-circuit refrigeration system. OK Foods established; programs, procedures and safety devices to prevent exposure to personnel, community and surrounding enviroment also protect property assets. Policies have been created to comply with all Federal, State and Local regulations. OK Foods strives to prevent potential releases through continual, training and revisions of policies, programs and procedures. 



Emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies.  Working in conjunction with the Muldrow Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee to prepare for necessary notification of all affected neighbors.



2.  THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.



The primary purpose of the facility is the processing of poultry products. Utilizing one regulated substance above the threshold level: anhydrous ammonia.



Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant for the refrigeration system, cooling and freezing.  An outside company is used to fill our main receiver tank.  Piping then carries the ammonia to the needed refrigeration, cooling or freezing units.  Access to the site is restricted to facility refrigeration maintenance personnel, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



The maximum amount of ammonia stored at this facility is 61,969 pounds.



3.  THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS, INCLUDING ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCES FOR EACH REPORTED SCENARIO.



Worst Case Scenario

The worst case scenario would be failure of the largest receiver and a release of its entire contents in 10 minutes. OK Foods policy restricts the carrying amount at any time to 80% of capacity, b

ut for argument sake, the full amount being spilled has been examined.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor.  

Distance to endpoint: 2.9 miles

Population affected:  6,560

Alternative Scenarios

The alternative scenarios investigated included all suggested release scenarios each with its consequential threat zone and population affected as indicated in Title 40 Part 68:28.  Scenarios investigated include:



1.    Rupture Disk/Relief Valve failure - Distance to endpoint: 0.6 miles.  Population affected = 383.  Quantity leaked = 61,969 lbs/min X 480 min.



2.    Shipping container mishandling or breakage leading to a spill.  Distance to endpoint = 1.6 miles.  Population affected = 1,291.  Quantity leaked = 33,605 lbs in 3 hours.



3.    Transfer Hose Failure - Distance to endpoint: 3.6 miles.  Population affected = 8,149.  Total quantity leaked = 61,969 lbs.



4.    Pipe Leak- Distance to endpoint:  0.1 miles.  Population affected = 0.  Quantity leaked = 24,000 lbs.



5.    Vessel Leak - Distance to endpoint: 0.3 miles.  Population affected = 143.  Quantity leaked = 48,000 lbs.



It has been determined that scenario 4 is the most likely to occur.



4.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.



This OK Foods facility has had no accidents or releases in the last five (5) years.



5.  THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.



The management of the RMP program will be handled by Steven Chiamsachang, Plant Manager.  Mr. Chiamsachang will administrate in conjunction with the O. K. Foods management and personnel.  Other entities or organizations that will be coordinated with include the Sequoyah County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Muldrow Fire Department.



6.  THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS.



OK Foods facility complies with all applicable Federal, State and Local regulations including the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule.  Our personnel are trained about this during our Hazard Communications Trainin

g and through access to our Written Programs.  Our Refrigeration Maintenance operators receive combination of classroom and On-The-Job (OTJ) training.  They are given written and oral testing.  They are observed by senior maintenance staff and are able to demonstrate proper job skills and knowledge before they are permitted to conduct maintenance procedures on ammonia-containing equipment.  



7.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.



OK Foods work closely with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Muldrow Fire Department and HAZMAT team on emergency preparedness.  Periodically meeting are conducted to address any changes in the facility or any new concerns.  Company personnel are fitted and trained in the use of emergency response protective equipment.  Guidelines for their use and the procedures for response are established.  An emergency contact chain has been developed and maintenance, security, safety, and environmental personnel meet regularly to review processes and procedures.   



8.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.



Currently, OK Foods trains and tests all refrigeration technicians. Process Safety Management Program is reviewed and updated annually also the program is improved continuously through annual updates of our written program and annual training of our technicians.  We also take advantage of new technologies that are available.
